content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, the strategy here is to maximize my earnings over the course of 75 rounds. Let's analyze the possible strategies:

1. Always pick R ({R}): In this case, if my opponent also chooses R, we both earn 45$ per round. However, since I assume my opponent will not always choose R, I will have many instances where I get nothing (0$). Over 75 rounds, the number of times I pick R and my opponent picks B is likely to be significant, resulting in a lower total earnings compared to other strategies.

2. Always pick B ({B}): In this case, if my opponent also chooses B, we both earn 40$ per round. However, since I assume my opponent will not always choose B, there will be instances where I could have earned more (45$) by choosing R instead of B. Over 75 rounds, the number of times I pick B and my opponent picks R is likely to be significant, resulting in a lower total earnings compared to other strategies.

3. Strategy that maximizes earnings: To maximize earnings, the strategy should take advantage of the higher payout when choosing R while minimizing the instances where I get nothing (0$). One possible approach is to choose R when the number of rounds left is odd and choose B when the number of rounds left is even ({R,B}):
   - In odd-numbered rounds, I choose R. If my opponent also chooses R, we both earn 45$. If they choose B, I get 35$ and they get 0$. Since I only choose R on odd rounds, there will be fewer instances where I get nothing (0$).
   - In even-numbered rounds, I choose B. If my opponent also chooses B, we both earn 40$. If they choose R, I get 0$ but that happens less frequently because I only choose R on odd rounds.

By strategically choosing R and B depending on the round number, I can maximize my earnings over the course of 75 rounds compared to always choosing either R or B. The exact payout would depend on the specific choices made by my opponent, but this strategy ensures that I take advantage of the higher payouts when possible while minimizing instances where I get nothing (0$).
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.
